page.title: 04Flora and Fauna
page.content: Despite the disappearance of elms, trees abound. Woodshill Copse in the south has oak, beech, chestnut, birch, ash, whitebeam, sycamore, poplar, fir, hawthorn. There are hazels, willows, hollies and ancient hedges. At Walnut Tree Cottage (Gay Street) the walnut died but is replaced. Gaywood boasts an old mulberry tree. Hungerhill has yews, acacias, and avenues of pines. Deer roam freely everywhere and are a problem to some farmers and gardeners. Badgers are known, foxes plentiful and rabbits multiplying fast. English and French partridges are native; snipe, Canada geese and wild duck regularly visit farm ponds. Several barn owls are reported, also a sparrowhawk and occasional buzzards circling high. Gaystreet Farm has a Jerusalem donkey; two others at Harbolets give rides to mentally/physically disabled children.
